Empires & Puzzles Quinn Review: The Cosmic Chef of the Super Elemental Family

Quinn brings a Pineapple Barbeque to the battlefield, serving up boosted health and buff immunity. But with two years of power creep on the menu, is his fast-speed support enough to satisfy modern appetites? We dig into the data.
Quinn Review: Is This Cosmic Chef Still Cooking?
Quinn, The Cosmic Chef: Serving Pineapples and Pain at Fast Speed

Quinn is a Legendary Ice hero from the Super Elemental family, originally released in September 2023. At first glance, he appears to be a jovial, space-faring pirate chef, but his kit is designed to disrupt enemy momentum while keeping your team healthy. He is a Fast speed healer who boosts health and blocks enemy buffs—a potent combination. While he hails from a time before the massive stat explosions of late 2024 and 2025, his utility effects have allowed him to cling to relevance longer than many of his peers. He doesn't have a costume yet, so this review focuses on his base form, which is currently the only item on the menu.

Quinn's design is certainly unique. He's a large, bearded figure with a cybernetic arm that seems to be functioning as a rotisserie or serving tray for glowing pineapples. The background suggests a cosmic setting, reinforcing the "Super Elemental" theme of being otherworldly. The vibrant colors—bright blues, oranges, and the glowing fruit—make him stand out against the typically grim or high-fantasy aesthetic of many other heroes. He looks like he's having a great time, which is more than can be said for the enemies about to be hit by his skill.

When we look at Quinn's stats in the context of late 2025, the reality of power creep sets in. His base power of 954 and stats hovering around the 900-970 mark were respectable in 2023 but are now significantly behind the curve. Modern Legendary heroes, like the Titan Hunters or Astral Demons released recently, boast base stats well over 1300 and power ratings exceeding 1250.

Quinn's defense of 968 is now comparable to modern 4-star heroes or even some 3-star costumes with limit breaks. While his health pool is decent, his survivability relies heavily on his ability to fire his special quickly rather than soaking up damage with raw stats. He is stat-wise considered
, and he desperately needs Limit Breaks and emblems to survive a single hit from a modern sniper.

"Pineapple Barbeque" is a busy skill with a lot of moving parts. First and foremost, it provides a 400 HP boost to all allies at Fast speed. Boosted health is always premium, effectively acting as a shield against max-HP reduction heroes. The secondary primary effect is the
for 3 turns to all enemies. This is arguably the most valuable part of his kit today, shutting down taunters, buffers, and dodge heroes before they can set up.
The elemental debuffs are the "seasoning" of this dish:
Mana generation down (-38%). Extremely potent for slowing down purple tanks or flanks.
Defense down (-38%). Helps your team deal more damage.
Attack down (-38%). Reduces incoming damage from his weak element.
While the healing amount (400) is low by modern standards (where healers often push 45%-50% or flat 800+ boosts), the combination of speed and disruption keeps it functional.

. He charges in 8 tiles. With a level 29 Magic/Styx troop or a high-level Mana troop (need +15% total mana bonus including talents), he can charge in 7 tiles. This 7-tile breakpoint is crucial for him to fire before the enemy heavy hitters.
400 Boosted Health. For a team with an average max HP of 2500 (common in late 2025), this is roughly a
. This is very low compared to pure healers who might heal 40-50%. However, since it is
The -38% mana generation against Dark enemies is significant. In a standard match, this can delay a slow purple hero by 2-3 turns effectively if they can't cleanse it.
Family Bonus, Passives, Aether Power & Unique Abilities
The Super Elemental family brings mechanics that revolve around elemental gems and troop damage.

The family bonus generates Power Gems on the board. While the damage (20 per turn / 10 to all when matched) is negligible against heroes with 3000+ HP, it adds up over a long fight and can help chip away at enemies or finish off low-HP targets. It's a nice bonus but not a game-changer.

is the key passive here. Quinn deals extra damage to Fire enemies with tiles (great for titans or mono teams) and takes less damage from Nature enemies. This mitigation helps him survive slightly longer against green snipers, although given his older stats, "slightly longer" might still mean "dead in two hits instead of one."

is his Limit Break 2 power. He gains a 60% counterattack for 6 turns at the start of the battle. Honestly, this is a bit of a mismatch for him. As a healer/support, you don't necessarily want him taking hits, and his defense isn't high enough to make the reflected damage lethal compared to a dedicated riposte hero. It offers some deterrence against AoE openers but is generally considered one of the weaker alpha powers for a support hero.

Upon release, Quinn was a very desirable hero. A Fast boosted healer who could block buffs was a direct answer to the heavy buff meta of the time. He was seen as a versatile support who could fit into almost any team.

The game has moved on. The healing creep has been massive, with recent heroes healing double what Quinn does. The stats gap is the biggest hurdle; Quinn simply melts under the pressure of 2025 damage dealers who bypass defenses or deal massive raw damage. His debuffs are still useful, but they are tied to specific elements, making him inconsistent.
Quinn has transitioned from a top-tier defender to a

. He is no longer viable on defense in top wars due to his fragility. However, in wars or tournaments (especially Bloody Battle or Buff Booster), his speed and buff immunity make him a valuable tool for attacking specific teams. He is a "problem solver" rather than a "stat stick."
Maximizes his ability to survive long enough to fire. His base defense is his biggest liability now, so every point counts.
Lowers his tile damage, but he isn't a damage dealer anyway.
Increases tile damage, leveraging his passive against red enemies.
He becomes made of glass. Not recommended for modern PvP.
path is the only logical choice. You bring Quinn to heal and block buffs; he can't do that if he's dead.
Fast mana allows him to stabilize the team and apply pressure quickly.
One of the best ailments in the game, completely shutting down heroes like Ludwig, Hathor, or modern buffers.
Always useful, negating max HP reduction ailments.
400 HP is a "band-aid" rather than a full recovery in the current meta of 3000+ HP heroes.
You can't rely on the mana slow or accuracy blind unless you are facing specific colors.
He deals no direct damage with his special, meaning he relies on teammates to win the match.
He is a superstar here. Even though he can't heal, the Buff Immunity prevents the enemy from using their defensive buffs, and he still generates Power Gems.
His speed and buff immunity are perfect counters to the format.
As a counter-pick against heavy buff teams or Dark tanks.
His passive increases tile damage significantly against weak elements.

Use Quinn to prevent the enemy from setting up defenses. Pair him with other fast heroes to overwhelm the enemy before they can recover. If you can fire Quinn before a taunter like Phorcys or Ludwig fires, you've essentially neutralized them.
Quinn provides the initial fast stability and buff block, buying time for average/slow heavy hitters to charge. His tile damage passive helps soften up red targets for the snipers.
Faster heroes who can silence or drain mana (e.g., fast snipers) will kill him before he fires. Cleansers (War Equalizer rule or heroes like Shaur) remove his precious Buff Immunity.
Do not rely on him as a solo healer in a team of modern behemoths; his 400 HP heal won't keep a 3000 HP hero alive under heavy fire.

If you pulled Quinn early, you have a gem. He will carry you through map stages and early raids with ease. His boosted health makes hard mode stages much more forgiving. Prioritize leveling him as your main blue healer until you find someone with modern stats.

Quinn is a bench warmer for most top-tier activities, but don't feed him away. He retains value in War depth (specifically for his Buff Immunity) and is still excellent in 5-star tournaments where his speed shines. Do
use Alpha Aethers on him unless you absolutely love him or lack modern 5-star healers entirely; the resources are better spent on heroes with 2025-era stats.
When Quinn was released, the community was split. Some loved the "Pineapple Barbeque" theme, finding it hilarious. Others were skeptical about the low healing number even back then.
"He looks like the love child of Ariel & Jequn"
— A forum user noting his visual similarities.
"Is no one mentioning the pineapple bbq? That is so atrociously disgusting..."
— A user questioning the culinary choices.
"Being able to tell a myriad of healers, damage sharers, reflecters, taunters, etc., a big old NOPE, at fast speed, is a superpower indeed."
— A player recognizing the true value of his kit lies in the ailment, not the heal.

Historically, he was part of the wave of "Super Elemental" heroes that tried to encourage mono-color play, though his skills actually work best when countering specific enemy colors rather than stacking your own.

Quinn is a hero who has aged gracefully in utility but poorly in physique. His "Pineapple Barbeque" is still a recipe for success thanks to the powerful Buff Immunity and Fast speed, but his low stats mean he needs to be carefully protected. He isn't the meta-breaking monster he might have been if released today with 1400 defense, but he remains a fun, flavorful, and tactically useful tool for those who know when to serve him up.
A delicious side dish, but no longer the main course. Keep him for tournaments and specific counter-play.
